author: guypbenson

text: Marie asked Schultz about the top geopolitical threat America is currently facing. His answer was Russia which he calls an “enemy of the United States.” He added that China presents a serous challenge, but not an enemy.
author: guypbenson

text: On SCOTUS, I pressed Schultz on the sort of “consensus” nominee he’d look for. Does that exist anymore? Do any of the current 9 fit his mold? He decried “revenge politics” in these fights — & eventually cited CJ John Roberts. “A wonderful example of what we are talking about.”
author: guypbenson

text: Schultz cites GHW Bush and LBJ as strong VP models he’d seek to emulate in picking a running mate, but hints that he may be inclined to select a woman.
author: guypbenson

text: ...Says Trump v Sanders/socialist would be a “very very poor choice” for the country, which would likely lead to the “tragic” outcome of Trump’s re-election...
author: guypbenson

text: We asked Schultz if there’s any Democrat in the race that he would NOT vote for over President Trump, if Schultz is not in the race on Election Day 2020. He ultimately told us that hypothetical personal vote choice would be “private.”
author: guypbenson

text: Schultz calls Beto a “welcome” voice in the 2020 race/conversation, casts doubt on whether he can win a primary within a party he says is moving hard to the Left.

text: I personally suspect much of this statement is true, though Cohen is unquestionably a deeply embittered and disgruntled former employee with an enormous axe to grind. He’s also been convicted of lying under oath. I take anything he cannot definitively prove with a chunk of salt.

text: People who love Trump will furiously dismiss virtually all of what Cohen is saying as self-serving sour grapes & pandering to the opposition. Those who hate Trump will eagerly lap up every scathing word and anecdote.

text: Importantly, Cohen says Trump did not direct him to lie to Congress (though he argues it was implied) — another blow to Buzzfeed’s story — and that he has no direct evidence of Russian collusion (but he says he has suspicions).

text: The president’s ethics are poor. The portrait/straw purchaser allegation (w/ documentation) is an almost-comical vignette of petty ego & ethical bankruptcy. The Stormy hush payments seem undeniable. I’m dubious that they constitute a crime that justifies impeachment.

text: Addendum: As explored below w/ @chrislhayes, I should’ve said “many” not “most” don’t show up for adjudication. % of no-shows is substantially lower among bona fide asylum-seekers, vs larger population of non-detained illegal immigrants. ~80% of asylum claims aren’t granted.
author: guypbenson

text: As for the relative severity of the overall problem and where it should fall on the national priority list, that’s obviously a subjective judgment. My “ranking” probably falls somewhere between yours and the president’s.
author: guypbenson

text: Visa overstays are certainly a major challenge, as well. No argument from me on that.
author: guypbenson

text: Well we know that only ~20% of those claims are granted, while roughly one third are outright rejected. The others fall by the wayside etc. There absolutely *are* some significant # of false/baseless claims. There’s also all the illegal immigrants who make no asylum claim at all.
author: guypbenson

text: All *in that program.* Overall, genuine asylum seekers do show up for proceedings at a much higher rate than overall non-detained illegal immigrants.
author: guypbenson

text: Seeking asylum is not illegal. Falsely “seeking asylum” is an abuse of our system that creates thorny challenges.
author: guypbenson

text:
I shouldn’t have said that “most” don’t show up for proceedings — that’s not accurate — but many non-detained immigrants do not: ~25-40% according to this data https://www.justice.gov/eoir/page/file/fysb16/download#page=49 …

No-shows are def lower among bona fide asylum seekers. But many do not fit that bill.
author: guypbenson

text: Most asylum claims are illegitimate & many people simply cross illegally, never seeking asylum. ‘Catch and release’ is an ongoing, dysfunctional byproduct of the existing system, which increases population of illegal immigrants in US, most of whom don’t show up for adjudication.
author: guypbenson

text: Mitchell's examination raises numerous causes for skepticism, which =/= "attacking" Ford, or calling her a liar.  I have no interest in that.  I have an interest in determining whether a lone, uncorroborated story from the 80s is sufficient to kill a SCOTUS nomination...
author: guypbenson

text: I have no idea what did, or did not, happen in Maryland roughly three-and-a-half decades ago. A decades-old he said/she said cannot be adjudicated easily or perhaps at all here, considering the lack of evidence.  The evidence we *do* have must be examined...
author: guypbenson

text:
As others have noted, various media "fact checks" of Kavanaugh testimony have been weak, misleading & tendentious on multiple points.  See here: https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/rachel-mitchells-memo-is-damaging-to-christine-blasey-fords-case-against-brett-kavanaugh …

And here:
author: guypbenson

text: I summarize the aforementioned inconsistencies re: number of attackers, "early" vs "mid" 1980's, 15 vs "late" teens, & hearing vs. not hearing conversations HERE: https://townhall.com/tipsheet/guybenson/2018/10/01/draft-n2524169 …
author: guypbenson

text: Mitchell also raises other points -- including fair Q's about Ford's detailed memories about non-assault details from the party (1 beer, 0 meds), but her total lack of memory of other significant non-assault details from just before & just after the party (car ride to/from)...
author: guypbenson

text: Fourth: In her letter to Feinstein, Ford said she remembers hearing her alleged assailants' conversations with other partygoers while hiding in the bathroom. During testimony, she said she doesn't remember that...
author: guypbenson

text: Third: In her initial text message contact w/ WaPo this summer, Ford said alleged incident occurred in the *MID*-1980s. She wrote to Feinstein that it occurred in the early 80's.  She then wrote for her polygraph that it was the early 80's, but scratched out the word "early"...
author: guypbenson

text: Second: Per WaPo, Ford's therapy notes (no portions of which have been shared with the committee) say she disclosed that she was attacked in her "LATE teens." 15 does not qualify as 'late teens' under any reasonable definition...
author: guypbenson

text: First: Per WaPo, Ford's '12 therapy notes say she was attacked by 4 boys. Ford says it was 2, but that there were 4 boys at the party. Her recollection of the # of attendees at the gathering has changed several times, & *nobody* she places at the house corroborates her claim...
author: guypbenson

text: Discrepancies & inconsistencies therefore cannot be dismissed as nitpicky irrelevancies. On this score, I'll note four points -- all of which veteran sex crimes prosecutor Rachel Mitchell also enumerated in her thorough and dispassionate review of the evidence...
author: guypbenson

text: Because there is zero contemporaneous corroboration of her allegation (and because her accusation is the only one that appears credible based on the available evidence, for reasons I detail in my analysis), her memory & her 2012 therapy notes form the crux of this case...
author: guypbenson

text: THREAD: I spent some of the weekend reviewing several inconsistencies in Dr. Ford's account of what allegedly happened to her ~36 years ago. As I've said before, she did not strike me as someone who invented her story. But human memory is a tricky & unreliable thing...

text: To clarify: “We’re almost there” isn’t a reference to Kavanaugh or the atmospherics surrounding his nomination. It’s about people of a certain generation approaching the age where serious power is in the offing & a thought experiment re social media’s effect on confirmations.
author: guypbenson

text: Chronologically, we are almost there. And part of my point is that social media postings, comments & private messages will almost certainly play into PR battles over allegations. This seems obvious. OTOH: More opportunities to present vindicating evidence.
author: guypbenson

text:
Take a moment to imagine what high-stakes confirmation processes will look like once the social media generation is old enough to be up for powerful government jobs. 

Snapchat screen shots. ‘Liked’ tweets. Controversial memes. 

We’re almost there.

text: Earlier today, I made a few points about Rudy Giuliani's latest statements while co-hosting @OutnumberedFNC...then Rudy Giuliani *called into the show,* live, to respond/clarify. Here's my analysis of our exchange:
author: guypbenson

text: My points were apparently compelling enough to prompt Rudy to call into the show, unplanned, and clarify for 25 mins on live TV.
author: guypbenson

text: Rudy later added, unprompted, that his blanket denial about 2016 collusion was about the Trump campaign’s *upper echelon.*
author: guypbenson

text: Rudy called into @OutnumberedFNC after I highlighted apparent moved goalposts in his a.m. interviews. I asked if it’s still Team Trump’s position that there was 0 collusion w/ Russia. Rudy said yes. Also asked if they maintain Trump didn’t know about tower mtg beforehand. A: Yes.
author: guypbenson

text: He used the term “second meeting.” And he said it’s Cohen supposedly alleging it, not Davis.
author: guypbenson

text: We drilled down, asking why he’d insist Trump wasn’t at a meeting nobody ever claimed Trump had attended. Rudy said he was referring to a SECOND meeting Cohen will/is alleging. Rudy says that meeting never happened. So why not just say that, rather than deny Trump’s attendance?
author: guypbenson

text: That was our reaction.
author: guypbenson

text: As for my point about Rudy twice denying this morning that Trump was AT the Trump Tower/Russia meeting (which no one was alleging), Rudy told us he was referring to an alleged *SECOND* meeting (not made public until just now)...which Rudy then denied have even taken place.
author: guypbenson

text: Wow. After we discussed these points, Rudy *called in live* to @OutnumberedFNC to clarify and correct for ~25 minutes. That was...really something.
author: guypbenson

text:
As I just said on Fox, in multiple interviews this morning, Rudy appeared to shift goalposts on collusion & twice denied that Trump was *at* the Trump Tower meeting...which no one is alleging. 

If this is something other than off-the-cuff/muddled punditry, that’s worrisome.
author: guypbenson

text: #ShockedFace
author: guypbenson

Team Trump, forever: We absolutely did not collude with the Russians. Period, end of story.

Is he freelancing as a quasi-pundit, or is this a legal team pivot?

text:
I am young enough never to have really encountered “but Watergate” as a counterpoint.

“But Bush”? Sure.

I agree that some whataboutism is ok (especially if it’s closer to aboutism) & that excessive whataboutism is a deflecting crutch.

My tweet was just a rote dig at the NYT.
author: guypbenson

text: The tweet I sent out at the very same time stipulated that these things are not the same. I just had a chuckle at the Times writing about a media outlet crossing into politics, which the anti-tax reform direct action certainly did. It wasn’t corrupt, but it was not journalism.

text: If a college speaker is disinvited, is she not silenced in some way because someone else can invite her to speak? I’m not saying Kevin’s entire career has been, well, hanged. But I think this is a bad episode.

text: That was something to consider before hiring him. And I’m not sure it’s persuasive to argue that getting fired for one’s views isn’t a form of silencing because one can get another job somewhere else. https://twitter.com/kirstenpowers/status/982355047324504066 …

text: I didn’t say you are only worth listening to when you confirm my views. I’ve watched and read you for years, even when I think you’re wrong. text: Their slogan rejects adherence to party or clique and they chose to hire Kevin, knowing exactly what they were getting. No one is arguing that they had to *hire* him. We’re questioning the firing. https://twitter.com/kirstenpowers/status/982352724304904192 …

author: guypbenson

text: .@KirstenPowers -- who wrote a book lamenting the Left's silencing of views -- has endorsed The Atlantic's firing of Kevin Williamson.
